content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Tartar is a combination of plaque and minerals from saliva that harden on the surface of teeth. A dentist plans to conduct a study to investigate the following claim made by a toothpaste manufacturer. Toothpaste L is less effective at preventing tartar buildup on teeth than Toothpaste M. The dentist will randomly assign <math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to use one of two toothpastes, with <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Toothpaste L each day and the remaining <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Toothpaste M each day. Before the study begins, each person will receive a teeth cleaning to remove any tartar buildup. After one month, the dentist will measure the tartar buildup of each person and the number of people who have tartar buildup will be recorded for each toothpaste. (a) Describe the benefit of randomly assigning the type of toothpaste to the volunteers.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Tartar is a combination of plaque and minerals from saliva that harden on the surface of teeth. A dentist plans to conduct a study to investigate the following claim made by a toothpaste manufacturer. Toothpaste L is less effective at preventing tartar buildup on teeth than Toothpaste M. The dentist will randomly assign <math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to use one of two toothpastes, with <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Toothpaste L each day and the remaining <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Toothpaste M each day. Before the study begins, each person will receive a teeth cleaning to remove any tartar buildup. After one month, the dentist will measure the tartar buildup of each person and the number of people who have tartar buildup will be recorded for each toothpaste. (a) Describe the benefit of randomly assigning the type of toothpaste to the volunteers.

(b) Describe a process that can be used to randomly assign the <math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to the two toothpastes.

The following segmented bar graph shows the results of the study. (c) For the <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers in the study, is there support for the manufacturer’s claim? Justify your answer using values from the segmented bar graph. Do not perform an inferential procedure.

The dentist conducted a hypothesis test to investigate the manufacturer’s claim. Let <math alttext="p sub L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would experience tartar buildup with Toothpaste L and <math alttext="p sub M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would experience tartar buildup with Toothpaste M. The hypotheses of the test are: <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub L equals p sub M. H sub a: p sub L is greater than p sub M." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="p hat sub L minus p hat sub M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>L</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal.

(e) Based on the hypothesis test and resulting <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of <math alttext="0.002" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.002</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what can the dentist conclude about the manufacturer’s claim? Explain your answer.

topic.text: 1.4: Representing a Categorical Variable with Graphs

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Identify key and relevant information to answer a question or solve a problem.
